questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG tracing shown below?
questions.solution:
Right bundle branch block - features

  • QRS duration > 120 msec
  • RSR pattern in V1-V3
  • Wide slurred S waves in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-V6)

Left Bundle branch block - features

  • QRS duration > 120 msec
  • Absent Q wave in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5, V6)
  • Tall, monomorphic R wave in lateral leads
  • Deep S wave in V1 and V2

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1915

choices.text: It is a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor
It is a hydroxymethyl coenzyme A inhibitor
It is an ADP receptor antagonist

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the action of clopidogrel?
questions.solution:
• Clopidogrel prevents platelet aggregation through antagonism of the adenosine diphosphate (ADP) receptor.
  • It has been shown to reduce mortality from stroke and ischaemic heart disease (IHD) in primary prevention studies.
  • Vorapaxar is an anti-platelet agent that reduces platelet aggregation through reversible antagonism of Protease Activated Receptor-1 (PAR 1), also known as thrombin receptor.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page no: 2060

questions.text: The drug of choice in a patient with torsades de pointes is:
questions.solution:
• Torsades de pointes are characterised by twisting pattern of ventricular tachycardia in ECG that occurs in the background of prolonged QT interval
  • The drugs, metabolic abnormalities etc. that can prolong QTc can potentially lead to torsades de pointes.
  • IV Magnesium sulphate given at a bolus dose of 1-2 gm is considered to be effective in this condition and is considered the treatment of choice
  • Metoprolol and lignocaine may also be effective in some cases but are not the first line agents.
  • Amiodarone is avoided in such patients as it can further prolong the QTc interval

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1924

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of fatigue, weight loss, night sweats and a degree of exertional dyspnea. Her past history includes a prosthetic mitral valve replacement 2.5 years ago. Examination showed petechial hemorrhages in nails.ECHO confirms moderate paravalvular mitral regurgitation. Diagnosis of infective endocarditis was suspected and blood cultures are taken and a diagnosis of infective endocarditis made. What is the most likely culprit organism?
questions.solution:
• The commonest infective cause is Streptococcus viridans, accounting for around 40% of all cases.
  • Enterococcus species account for approximately 10% of cases, and they are more prevalent in the elderly.
  • Staphylococcus species account for around 25% of cases of endocarditis.

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis (First Year After Replacement):

  • In the first year following prosthetic valve replacement, the spectrum of infecting organisms is somewhat different.
  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci, primarily Staphylococcus epidermidis, are the most common, accounting for around 50% of cases.

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis (After the First Year Following Surgery):

  • After the first year following valvular surgery, the spectrum of infecting organisms is very similar to that for native valve endocarditis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1023

questions.text: Left axis deviation is seen on the ECG in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Causes of Left Axis Deviation:

  • Left anterior fascicular block
  • Left bundle branch block
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Inferior MI
  • Ventricular ectopy
  • Paced rhythm
  • Wolff-Parkinson White syndrome

Causes of Right axis deviation:

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Right bundle branch block
  • Left posterior fascicular block
  • Dextrocardia
  • Chronic lung diseases with cor pulmonale
  • Ventricular ectopic rhythms
  • Preexcitation syndrome (Wolff-Parkinson-White)
  • Lateral wall myocardial infarction
  • Secundum atrial septal defect

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1922

questions.text: A 44-year-old man attends for review. He has been suffering increasing shortness of breath over the past few years. Now he presents with a transient ischaemic attack (TIA), with weakness and coordination problems affecting his left side, which have resolved over the past 24 hours. On examination blood pressure is 142/95 mmHg and he is in sinus rhythm. There is no opening snap, but a diastolic murmur is heard which changes in character according to posture. Biochemical examination was unremarkable. Which of the following diagnoses fit best with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
This patient has suffered a TIA, most likely due to embolism from an intra-cardiac cause. Mitral stenosis with Atrial fibrillation is a possibility but there was no clinical evidence for the same and the patient was in sinus rhythm.

The presence of embolic phenomenon and the characteristic change of murmur at apex changing with posture suggest 'tumor plop' due to left atrial myxoma.

Left atrial myxoma

Myxomas are the most common intracardiac tumors

Myxoma can occur in any cardiac chamber, but occurs most commonly in the left atrium attached to interatrial septum. It is a gelatinous, friable tumour, which leads to transient signs of mitral stenosis that only occurs if the tumour approaches the mitral valve orifice. There may be an early diastolic plop as the tumour prolapses through the mitral valve.

Patient may present with embolic phenomenon, features of heart failure or constitutional features like fever, weight loss etc.

Atrial

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 2025-26

questions.text: The earliest ECG abnormality in a patient with hyperkalemia is:
questions.solution:
• ECG changes start to manifest usually when serum K > 6 mEq/L
  • The earliest ECG finding in a patient with hyperkalemia is tall, tented T waves
  • It is followed by other changes like P wave flattening, PR prolongation, QRS widening, appearance of sine wave pattern
  • Hypokalemia is characterised by ECG changes like T wave flattening/inversion, ST segment depression, appearance of 'u' wave and prolonged QU interval.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1911

choices.text: Squatting improves the cyanotic spells in children
Egg on side appearance in chest x-ray
Rastelli procedure is performed for surgical correction

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Tetralogy of Fallot

  • Most common cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • Components: pulmonary stenosis, VSD, overriding of aorta, RV hypertrophy
  • Characterised by cyanotic / tet spells during childhood while exertion
  • Squatting increases peripheral vascular resistance thereby reducing the magnitude of right to left shunt across VSD
  • Boot shaped heart or 'coeur en sabot' is the characteristic xray appearance

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, ch:264 pg:1833, 1834

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to casualty with severe chest pain. ECG was suggestive of anterior wall ST elevation MI. He underwent thrombolysis with reteplase with good resolution of ECG changes. On day 3, he developed sharp chest pain, worse with inspiration and movement and improved with NSAIDs. On day 5, patient has progressive dyspnea. His heart rate was 110/min, BP was 90/50 mmHg with elevated JVP. What is the most likely complication that has occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The presence of typical sharp chest pain which increases on inspiration is suggestive of pericarditis. However, it would not per se lead to hypotension and raised JVP as seen in this patient.
  • Cardiac tamponade can occur as a rare complication in post-MI patients. It is the rapid accumulation of fluid in pericardial sac under pressure.
  • The typical clinical triad seen in tamponade is 'Beck's triad' (low BP, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds)
  • The development of acute mitral regurgitation or VSD is associated with severe pulmonary oedema and less likely to be associated with chest pain.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page no: 2064

questions.text: A 15-year-old female developed rheumatic fever with carditis. There were no significant residual cardiac lesions. This patient needs to take prophylaxis for rheumatic fever until the age of ____.
questions.solution:
For patients with RF without carditis, prophylaxis to be given for 5 years after last attack or till 18 years, whichever is longer

For patients with carditis and no severe involvement and significant residual disease, prophylaxis for 10 years or till the age of 21, whichever is longer

For patients with severe valvular involvement / post-surgery, prophylaxis need to be instituted lifelong.

Our patient had carditis with no significant cardiac involvement, hence she need prophylaxis for 10 more years (till 25 years)

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1188

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is being reviewed at a medical outpatient clinic complaining of tiredness. He takes amiodarone, aspirin, atenolol and atorvastatin. His heart rate on examination is 85 bpm. Recent 2D.hr ECG shows sinus rhythm throughout with occasional ventricular ectopics. Investigations reveal: Free T4 32 nmol/l (9-22) TSH < 0.02 mU/l (0.D.4) What is the best management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient has probable amiodarone-induced hyperthyroidism.
  • The amiodarone was used to maintain sinus rhythm in this patient who was admitted with ischaemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation/flutter that spontaneously settled. The amiodarone should be discontinued, and carbimazole started. When the patient is euthyroid, the dose of carbimazole may be reduced (amiodarone can stay in the system for several weeks).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, page number:2710

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady has dental phobia but has finally gone to the dentist following severe toothaches and is told she has dental abscesses. She is brought into ER with high fevers by a relative. She is found to have a diastolic murmur in the aortic area. Which one of these is a sign of endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Blood on the urine dipstick indicates renal involvement due to microemboli from vegetations in endocarditis.

  • Roth's spots are vasculitic lesions on the retina – seen in infective endocarditis.
  • Splenomegaly occurs.
  • Bouchard's nodes occur in osteoarthritis.

Osler's nodes are small reddish tender areas on the pulp of fingers or toes. Janeway lesions are reddish spots on fingers or toes, but are painless. These are seen in infective endocarditis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, pg: 922,925,923-924,931-932

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to ER with severe acute chest pain radiating to the back. He is pale and anxious. On examination the blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and he was noted to have blue sclerae. Which of the following conditions has predisposed to this complication?
questions.solution:
Marfan's syndrome is one of the causes of blue sclerae. The clinical diagnosis is aortic dissection.

Disorders predisposing to aortic dissection are: essential hypertension, atherosclerosis, bicuspid aortic valve, connective tissue disorders, Marfan's syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, adult polycystic kidney disease.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a defect in the fibrillin-1 gene on chromosome 15.

Clinical features:

  • Tall stature with arm span to height ratio > 1.05
  • Upper to lower body ratio is decreased (head to symphysis pubis: symphysis pubis to toes).
  • High-arched palate
  • Arachnodactyly
  • Pectus excavatum
  • Pes planus
  • Scoliosis of > 20 degrees à Low back pain
  • Dural ectasia (ballooning of the dural sac at the lumbosacral level) – seen in 60% of patients. It may cause lower back pain associated with neurological problems such as bladder and bowel dysfunction like incontinence.
  • Heart - Dilatation of the aortic sinuses (seen in 90%) which may lead to aortic regurgitation, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection, and mitral valve prolapse (75%) which causes systolic murmur at mitral area.
  • Lungs: repeated pneumothoraxes
  • Eyes: Upwards lens dislocation (supertemporal ectopia lentis), blue sclera, retinal detachment and myopia.

The life expectancy of patients used to be around 40-50 years. With the advent of regular echocardiography monitoring and beta-blocker/ACE inhibitor therapy this has improved significantly over recent years.

Aortic dissection and other cardiovascular problems remain the leading cause of death however.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, ch:274 pg:1917

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with a four-hour history of fatigue and palpitations. On examination she is vomiting, and is noted to have a slight tremor, some lid lag and has an irregularly irregular pulse of 140 per minute, blood pressure 112/74 mm Hg. ECG confirms atrial fibrillation with a rate of approximately 130 per minute. Thyroid function tests show: Free T4 31.8 pmol/l (9-22) TSH 0.05 mu/l (0.5-4.5) Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Atrial fibrillation occurs in 5-15% of patients with thyrotoxicosis. AF associated with Thyrotoxicosis often spontaneously reverts to sinus rhythm when euthyroidism is restored, hence cardioversion should be withheld until antithyroid medication has been successful.

  • In stable patients with atrial fibrillation, a strategy of rate control The choice agent is guided by the hemodynamic status of the patient, associated conditions, and the urgency of achieving rate control.
  • In the stable patient with atrial fibrillation, a beta-blocker calcium channel blocker (orally or intravenously) is usually the first-line agent for ventricular rate control.
  • In the setting MI or ischemia, beta-blockers are the preferred agent. The most frequently used agents are either Metoprolol or, in unstable patients, esmolol
  • If beta-blockers are contraindicated, calcium channel blockers are rapidly effective.
  • Rate control using digoxin is slow (onset of action more than 1 hour with peak effect at 6 hours) and may be inadequate and is rarely indicated or used in the acute setting.
  • Similarly, amiodarone, even when administered intravenously, has a relatively slow onset and is most useful as an adjunct when rate control with the previously cited agents is incomplete or contraindicated or when cardioversion is planned in the near future

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, chapter:246 page number:1747

Reference: CMDT 2023, pg. 392

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with history of colorectal polyps presents with low grade fever, weight loss and night sweats. ECHO showed vegetations on the aortic valve. Which is the most likely organism to be grown in blood culture?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus bovis bacteremia and endocarditis have been strongly associated with colorectal neoplasia. Patient identified to have S. bovis endocarditis should be evaluated for the presence of colorectal polyps or cancer.

Penicillin G is the treatment of choice for S. bovis endocarditis typically given for 4 weeks.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most commonly isolated organism from endocarditis occurring in IV drug abusers, which preferentially affects the tricuspid valve.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1023-25

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has been very ill for months following the onset of chronic liver disease with hepatitis C infection and suspected transformation to hepatocellular transformation. He experiences a sudden loss of consciousness and then exhibits hemiplegia on the right. A cerebral angiogram reveals lack of perfusion in the left middle cerebral artery distribution. The most likely cardiac lesion to be associated with this finding is ?
questions.solution:
Marantic endocarditis / non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis has sterile, platelet-fibrin thrombi that are prone to embolize. This form of non-infective endocarditis can be seen in persons who are very debilitated or who have a hypercoagulable state.

The order of preference in involvement of valves in marantic endaocarditis is mitral > aortic > tricuspid > pulmonary.

Libman-Sacks endocarditis is characterized by sterile, verrucous valvular lesions with a predisposition for the mitral and aortic valves. Classically associated with SLE and less commonly Anti phospholipid antibody syndrome.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1024

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has effort-related angina. His total cholesterol is 212 mg/dl. He has no other cardiac risk factors and no other relevant medical history. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
The choice of first-line treatment for the prophylaxis of effort-related angina in someone without contraindications is a β-Blocker. β-Blockers also remain the choice in someone who has suffered a previous myocardial infarction.

Calcium-channel blockers - especially diltiazem and verapamil can be used, although they should be avoided in the presence of significant left ventricular dysfunction. Nitrates are of good value, but they come after β-Blockers.

Care should be taken before combining a β-Blocker and non-dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker, especially if there is evidence of conduction disturbance or LV dysfunction.

The Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study showed that a statin given to patients with angina pectoris and a cholesterol level of 212-308 mg/dl significantly reduced the risk of MI.

Aspirin would also of course be recommended for secondary prevention of ischaemic events and nitrates could be used for symptom relief.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page no: 2041

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient who has had chemotherapy for metastatic breast cancer 6 months earlier comes to the clinic complaining of shortness of breath on exertion. Her BP is 125/78 mmHg, her pulse is 94/min and her apex beat is displaced to the anterior axillary line. CXR - Cardiomegaly, increased shadowing consistent with mild pulmonary oedema at both bases Which chemotherapeutic agent is most likely to be responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin can be associated with cardiac failure, reduced left ventricular ejection fraction and tachyarrhythmias. Platinum based chemotherapies are associated with peripheral neuropathy, and bleomycin with interstitial pneumonitis and a specific skin lesion called 'flagellate dermatitis'.

Drugs causing dilated cardiomyopathy

  • Doxorubicin (Adriamycin)
  • Trastuzumab (Herceptin)
  • Tacrolimus
  • Zidovudine

Drugs like NSAIDs, Thiazolidinediones can cause fluid retention and thus worsen heart failure in patients with underlying disease.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 737,1964

choices.text: MI due to left anterior descending coronary artery occlusion

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented to the emergency department with chest discomfort and breathlessness after she heard the news about the demise of her husband. She had no fever, hypotension or syncope. ECG was suggestive of anterolateral wall ischemia. ECHO showed global ventricular dilation with ballooning of apex and basal contraction. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The condition described in question is Takotsubo cardiomyopathy a.k.a apical ballooning syndrome or acute stress induced cardiomyopathy. The ventricle shows global ventricular dilation with apical ballooning and hypercontractility of segments at the base.

Clinical presentation may mimic acute MI with features of angina, hypotension or pulmonary edema. Coronary angiogram is required to rule out coronary artery occlusion

Treatment includes beta blockers and Angiotension receptor blockers.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1966

questions.text: Which of the following is the most preferred modality for assessing myocardial viability?
questions.solution:
• PET scan is considered the gold standard in myocardial viability assessment. It can assess both myocardial blood flow and metabolic activity with different radiotracers.
  • Contrast enhanced MRI and dobutamine stress cardiac MRI also have high specificity especially for assessing ventricular function.
  • Radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging is done with either thallium-201 or technetium-99.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page no: 2037

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component assessed in NYHA functional classification in heart failure
questions.solution:
The NYHA Functional Classification categorizes heart failure patients based on their limitations during physical activity.

The clinical parameters assessed include undue fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea and angina. 

Class I: Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or anginal pain.

Class II: They are comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, and dyspnea.

Class III: Marked limitation of physical activity. Patients are comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary activity causes symptoms

Class IV: Symptoms of heart failure occur even at rest, and any physical activity exacerbates discomfort

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1798

choices.text: Cerebrovascular accident in the preceding one year

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute contraindication for fibrinolytic therapy in a patient with acute MI?
questions.solution:
Absolute contraindications for use of fibrinolytic therapy in MI

  • History of hemorrhagic stroke at any time
  • Cerebrovascular events in the preceding year
  • Systolic blood pressure > 180 mmHg or diastolic BP > 110 mmHg at any time during presentation
  • Suspicion of aortic dissection
  • Active internal bleeding excluding menstrual bleed.

Relative contraindications

  • Current use of anti-coagulants
  • Pregnancy
  • Recent (< 2 weeks) invasive surgical procedure
  • Prolonged (> 10 min) CPR
  • Active peptic ulcer disease
  • History of severe hypertension that is controlled at present

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page no: 2059

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with breathlessness, visual blurring and headaches to ER. During examination, he has a generalized tonic clonic seizure. He has a blood pressure of 240/120. Fundoscopy reveals retinal hemorrhages and exudates. The optic disc margin is not visualized. Which of the following medications is the first line?
questions.solution:
Malignant hypertension is defined as severely elevated blood pressure (BP > 180/120 mmHg) with evidence of new / progressive target organ damage.

Target organ damage may involve cardiovascular (MI, pulmonary edema). Renal (hematuria, worsening GFR), CNS (encephalopathy) or ophthalmic (hard exudates, papilledema).

The intravenous drugs used for urgent BP reduction in malignant hypertension include:

  • Sodium nitroprusside
  • Labetolol
  • Nitroglycerin
  • Nicardipine
  • Esmolol
  • Hydralazine
  • Fenoldopam

Sodium Nitroprusside has an immediate onset of action and short half-life. It acts by causing relaxation of vascular smooth muscle, resulting in vasodilation and inotropy. The dose is 0.25-10 mcg/kg/min IV.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 2086

questions.text: A 64-year-old female with heart failure was diagnosed to have non-valvular atrial fibrillation. Which of the following scores would help in guiding the need of anticoagulant therapy for stroke prevention?
questions.solution:
CHA2DS2-VASc score helps assess the risk of stroke in individuals with AF.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score includes several stroke risk factors:

  • C (Congestive heart failure): 1 point
  • H (Hypertension): 1 point
  • A2 (Age ≥75 years): 2 points
  • D (Diabetes Mellitus): 1 point
  • S2 (Prior Stroke or TIA or thromboembolism): 2 points
  • V (Vascular disease): 1 point
  • A (Age 65-74 years): 1 point
  • Sc (female sex): 1 point

A score of 2 or more strongly warrants the need for anticoagulation

TIMI score estimates the 14 day mortality / recurrent ischemic events in patients with unstable angina / NSTEMI

ACC-AHA pooled cohort equation estimates the 10 year ASCVD risk

HAS-BLED score gives the 1 year risk of major bleeding in a patient on oral anticoagulant therapy

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1031

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common infective cause of cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Chagas disease, caused by Trypanosoma cruzi and transmitted by reduviid bug is the most common infectious cause of cardiomyopathy. Typical features include conduction system abnormalities commonly AV blocks

Parvovirus B19, Coxsackie and Echoviruses are the most common infectious causes of myocarditis

Bacterial causes of myocarditis include legionella, salmonella, Corynebacterium diphtheria etc

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1972
